trial_identification.studytitle: the effect of splinting and exercises on swelling of the nerve in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of nerve and tendon gliding exercises and splinting on median nerve oedema in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome

interventions.interventions:
Patietns are randomly allocated to one of two interventional groups:
nerve and tendon gliding exercises: Ten repetitions of six different exercises are performed per session. One session takes approximately 2 minutes to complete. Participants are asked to complete 10 sessions per day for one week.
splinting: patients are wearing a wrist splint at night for one week.

primaryOutcome.outcome: median nerve signal intensity and carpal ligament bowing will be evaluated on magnetic resonance images (MRI) of the patients' wrists.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, immediately after one session of nerve and tendon gliding exercises or splinting (10minutes) and 1 week after baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: hand symptoms assessed using the Boston Carpal tunnel questionnaire, the s-LANSS scale (Leeds Assessment of neuropathic symptoms and signs), visual analogue scales for pain and numbness as well as the global rating of change scale.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, immediately after one session of nerve and tendon gliding exercises or splinting (10minutes) and 1 week after baseline.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: hand function assessed using the Boston Carpal tunnel questionnaire and the patient specific functional scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, immediately after one session of nerve and tendon gliding exercises or splinting (10minutes) and 1 week after baseline.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Systemic inflammatory diseases Diabetes mellitus Metal implants Previous wrist surgery or wrist fracture Traumatic onset of CTS Cervical radiculopathy or other neuropathy of the upper limb/neck Pregnancy associated CTS (or thought to be pregnant as MRI is a relative contraindication) Pending litigation Claustrophobia (MRI)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will investigate whether nerve and tendon gliding exercises or splinting are capable of reducing swelling intra- as well as extraneurally in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome.
